intro: Brassica rapa subsp. sarson, commonly known as wild mustard, is an annual herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, featuring erect stems and alternate, pinnately lobed leaves. The plant produces small, yellow flowers arranged in racemes, which bloom from late spring to early summer. Its seeds are enclosed in siliques, which are slender, elongated pods. This species is known for its rapid growth and adaptability to a variety of soil types.
